conclusion: Analyze the forces acting on the system to ensure the CD rope remains horizontal.
The weight of mass m exerts a downward force mg at point C.
The tension in the AC rope, TAC, acts upward and to the left.
The tension in the CD rope, TCD, acts horizontally to the right.
The tension in the BD rope, TBD, acts upward and to the left.
The tension in the CD rope, TCD, acts horizontally to the left.
An external force F is applied horizontally to the right to keep the CD rope level.
For point C to be in equilibrium, the vertical and horizontal components of the forces must balance.
For point D to be in equilibrium, the vertical and horizontal components of the forces must balance.
Vertical equilibrium at point C: TAC sin θ = mg.
Horizontal equilibrium at point C: TAC cos θ = TCD.
Vertical equilibrium at point D: TBD sin θ = 0, so TBD must be zero.
Horizontal equilibrium at point D: TCD = F.
Relate the tensions and angles: TAC cos θ = TCD and TAC sin θ = mg.
Express TAC in terms of TCD: TAC = mg / sin θ and TCD = mg cot θ.
Determine the minimum force F: F = mg cot θ.
Find the angle θ using geometry: cos θ = 1/2, θ = 60°.
Calculate cot θ for θ = 60°: cot 60° = 1/√3.
Substitute cot θ into the expression for F: F = mg / √3.
